Obviously the best poor boys in town! I love the huge crispy onion rings! I always get cheese & pickles on my poor boy & extra garlic! Why not? Just hate how I smell for the whole day & night!

Since I've only ever had poor boys, onion rings, mushrooms, salads, and twice baked potatoes any time I've ever come here (over 30 yearsof visits) I can only speak to those items.  Good stuff. It's by no means fine dining, just old fashioned grub. Unfortunately the prices are pretty ridiculous but sometimes a merichkas poor boy just his the spot. I sometimes go in thinking I'll try something else but the garlic seeping throughout the restaurant makes me go back to the old standard.  I think those poor boys have shrunk quite a bit in the last few years though. Twice baked potatoes awfully dry the last couple times we've been there (maybe go once or twice a year). I make the same salad dressing so all in all I can make it at home fresher,  cheaper, and tastier but then I'd have to do the dishes and it's nice to have a night off every once in awhile!

Love this place! It is so near and dear to my heart as my family has been having dinner every new years eve at Merichka's. The poor-boy is a must! In all the years we have been dining here, the food and service is always the same--great.

I grew up going here. Every time my stepfathers parents would come to town, off to Merichkas we would go. 

The best part about this place is the fried onion ring mushroom combo platter. Huge onion rings. Phenomenal fried mushrooms. 

People always say to get the poor boy. It's super greasy. You have to be ok with that. 

No sandwich comes with fries. It is always an additional charge.

You will never have a better poorboy than a Meritchka's poorboy!  Meritchka's is known for their awesome poorboy.  Make it a dinner with a double baked potato and WOW!  It's loaded with garlic butterine so this is something that we immensely enjoy once a year as a treat.  This place has been in Joliet for many years.  I remember going there as a child.

Once you have a Meritchka's poorboy, you will never find one that tastes better!

Merichka's.  Like potica, if you're not from Joliet, you'll never have the true appreciation for it.  For those of us local, it's not just food.  Merichka's is the place you go after a funeral.  It's the place you go after a first communion.  It's where the high school newspaper team went for our year-end dinner.  Merichka's isn't about the food as much as it's about the reason you're there.

The food is great...a piece of chopped steak over-saturated with garlic butter served in a bun that's also soaked in garlic butter.  Then there's the pickle and olive tray, the onion rings and salad.  These are all items I can still taste in my mouth and I haven't been there in years.

Everyone from Joliet has been to Merichka's and Al's in the same weekend (possibly Aurelios / Cemino's too).  It's not just a place to love for the food alone, but for the big family parties there.  Being a kid and chasing your cousins around the table.  Being an adult now, Merichka's is the post-funeral meal (Al's is the post-wake Dinner). I went there after burying my grandma (who was friends with Merichka), my aunt and my father (who used to work there when he was a young man). There's something very comforting about knowing that it'll be there.  It's a stable constant in this world.

So, for everyone who goes there for the first time expecting a life changing meal, you're going to be disappointed. It doesn't taste like childhood to you.  You don't remember being there as a little kid in your Sunday best.  You don't remember how the pickles taste exactly the same 30 years later, or how the walls feel like home. You're going there expecting something that can no way be delivered this late in your life. It doesn't remind you of your grandma.

Much like potica, Merichka's just tastes awesome if you're from Joliet. If you're not, then go ahead and give it a try buy manage your expectations.

Worlds greatest Poorboy. The original.  Over 60 years old. 
Others try, and fail. 
If you want an real and original Poorboy sandwich, you must go to Merichka's

Place is a rip off. Food is OK at best. Come on...it's a Poor Boy (po boy) however you want to say it. It's a cheap piece of meat on a bun with garlic butter and cheese for TEN BUCKS! Plus over $5 more if you want to add a salad and fries. I can get a much better meal elsewhere for over fifteen bucks than basically a fast food place. If someone put the plate in front of me and asked what I would pay I would say about 8-10 at most.

This restaurant will always have sentimental value to me as it was where my parents ate the night before I was born. From what I was told, after I entered the world, my mother's roommate's family brought in bags of poorboy sandwiches from Merichka's.  These days, the poorboy sandwich is still delicious(although smaller than I remember) as is the  house dressing. 

Also, I have yet to try onion rings as good as Merichka's. Thanks for the memories, past and future.

We dropped in without a reservation on a Sunday night.  We had to wait around 10 minutes to be seated in a nice, heated foyer area.

One seated (kind of reminds you of your mom's place - big tables!), we got our order in quickly. We started with a small order of onion rings, which were supposed to be for 2 or 3 people, and were more like for 4 or 5 people.  Unless you are big eaters, you'll leave some behind.  The onion rings were very good.

I ordered their 10 ounce filet, and my wife went with their poor boy, which was so big, she had to take around half home.

Dinner comes with a relish tray and salad, and both were fresh and tasty.

We had a good time.  The ambiance is a little (okay, a lot) dated.  It could use an update, but the food is fine, and the price won't break the bank.

No free WIFI if you need that.

Joliet.    Look out I'm coming home for a visit. 
Can not wait to go back to old fav's.  Merichka's is definitely one of those. 
Load up on those cholesterol pills. It's hot dogs, poor boys, pizza (deep of course) and Midwestern beef. 
So miss the food of my youth.
God Bless Joliet!!!!!
I always have to eat here while visiting family in Joliet .  I dream of coming back and having a poorboy ! The poorboy beef is the best sandwich I have ever eaten !! I can't wait to visit again.

Merichka's is a local landmark. The food never disappoints!

If you're a garlic fan, you must have the poorboy sandwich. I order it with american cheese and raw onion...hint.

One should also try their onion rings, double baked potatoes, and a salad with Merichka's house dressing.

Plan on tasting the garlic the following day! It's a good thing!

A Joliet favorite! You get what you pay for here, nothing more and nothing less. The atmosphere is very old and they've only recently made updates to some aspects of the restaurant.

I usually get the Yodel Burger (comes with cheese) which is like a Poorboy but with hamburger meat. It is very greasy, as is anything you order here. I also usually get a house salad with ranch dressing which is pretty good. Salads come with the cracker basket which is my favorite part!

Most of the servers are older. Our waitress this past Monday had a little attitude, but nothing too bad.

As long as you know it's a local, small business and aren't expecting TOO much this is a fun place to go once in awhile.

Great huge beer prices & onion rings. The poor boy is GOD AWFUL! I have no idea how or why anyone would like that sandwich. It's a soggy greesy garlic mess. Not in a good way. My plans for this evening are no more. They should serve it to u while you are on the toilet. How can so many people be wrong you say?? No idea!! It was disgusting!! I brought 3 guest with me and I'm sure NONE of them will ever take my recommendation again. By the way. When you serve someone a beer. It's a good idea to not have your fingers in it when you pass it to the patron. That's it!! One less star!
Good ole Merichka's... they haven't been around this long for no reason.  Get a poor boy with extra garlic butter!

Service was on the slow side- it was the dinner rush on a Friday and they were packed- but also really friendly.

The steaks- filet and ribeye- were great; pike was just okay. The double-baked potatoes were thick and huge- that's what she said! 

Look, you can't compare this place to a chain, or a steakhouse downtown... so don't.

For where you are and what you're paying, you can't beat the food coma you're sure to end up in!

This is one of my favorite old school restaurants that are unique and special. The poor boys are awesome but so are the burgers, chicken and fish. I always go for the poor boys but end up getting something else and am always happy with my choice. 

Great selection of drinks and a comfortable atmosphere.

I love this place and only for one reason and one reason only. I only go here for their po boy steak sandwich. you have not lived till you tried it. But you have to order it a special way. You have to get it with cheese and grilled onions. It comes on a garlic butter toasted roll with fires. Its pretty basic but the flavors just explode in your mouth, my mouth is watering as I type this. I think I'm having a foodgasm. The service is friendly and polite and the setting is like really old school like back in the day 1930s type of restaurant. but I don't care I will be back for the po boy sandwich and their onion rings aren't bad either. Its real onions that big enough to share between two or three people. I highly recommend this place if your in the area

Never seems to fail! My family & I always come here and get the poorboys. Perfectly made and always delicious, service is just as great as the environment. Great place to wind down with family after a big event. One of the Joliet Classics

This restaurant has satisfied generations of my family members before me and I'm just catching on now...

We gladly make the drive out from the Chicago area to indulge in those giant onion rings and p-boy sandwiches. The best part of this place for me is that they aren't trying to be something they're not. The interior is dated and simple and the food is a throwback to a time when transfats, carbs and high fructose corn syrup were not dirty words. So if you're into healthy eating and you're a gluten-free, organic vegan you might find yourself in hell here at Merichka's. With that being said, I'm a "healthy eater" and I make exceptions for places like this. I could bathe in the garlic butter that drips off the poorboys when you bite into them, they're that good. Always order them with cheese and grilled onions. I mean, go big or go home right?

Good Food. Good Service. Great Times. MUST GET A POORBOY!

A friend took me here and here ordered for me a : Poorboy with Onions and Swiss Cheese. Man am I glad he did. It was unforgettable ( You Must Like Garlic Butter). I now do the same I bring people here and order for them since they are new-by's, and everyone is always very happy. I have also had the there Fish which is great some of the best I've had next to fresh caught. All the sides are good. Onions rings are a must. 

Service is wonderful. You'll Be Happy.

ALL THE SERVERS ARE CPR TRAINED,, I REPEAT ALL SERVERS ARE CPR TRAINED....... (probably not)

This is the dream I have which justify's me to scarf down there onion rings (best I ever had) and devour there Steak Poorboy.

Not a Po-Boy that you'd find in Louisiana, but a totally different creature, one I found that you could duplicate, but never replicate. It's a sandwich of Mona Lisa beauty, but Jennifer Lopez taste. The perfect sandwich, where you say to yourself "I'll cut in half I swear" of course this never happens. It's too good.

The Poorboy consists of a soft hockey bun, a tender slab of steak, onions cheese and melted butter, butter, butter. Some how it works, and works to a tee!

If I only I could convince my cardiologist.

I cannot believe I've never reviewed this place. It has been a long time since I had been to Merichkas and I had a craving for a poorboy. The sandwich by itself is 8 bucks and with fries takes it to 12!? 4 dollars for fries is a bit much. Fries are cheap people!
            One thing that was lacking from my meal is salt. The fries had no salt or seasoning whatsoever. Very expensive and bland fries. I did however enjoy the combination of pickles with the fries. I totally felt like a pregnant chick eating that but it was kinda good. 
      As for my poorboy- it was good, but not like everyone makes it out to be. The meat itself has really no flavor to it. It's the garlic bread and the pickles that made the poorboy taste better than what it was. Eating my poorboy brought back old memories of when I ate there before. The food was just average then and still is today.  Old people love this place.
            Will I eat at Merichkas again? Yes. It wasn't bad, but I don't get all the raving over bland food. I think it's the old time atmosphere and nostalgic childhood memories that people love about this place but the food simply isn't all that. #SorryBoutIt #GurlBye
Another great dinner. They said it would be an hour and a half for the wait to be seated but ended up only taking 45mins. I love the poor boy, I get one to go as well.

Always the same. Great food. Good service. I get a poorboy or 1/4 fried chicken - all white meat. Double baked potato. The onion rings are great. House dressing is a very sweet homemade French dressing. They put lots on so I always ask for it on the side. Cocktails are old school but very good. 
I think if you didn't come here as a kid you might not "get it" but don't come looking for healthy fare. It is what it is and they have been at it a long time.
Always a crowd pleaser. Been going there for 50 years on and off. I never had a disappointment. The steaks are always fresh never frozen.  And the garlic butter is to die for.

3 stars overall, 5 stars for the steak poorboy - it is great.  The sandwich is hot, moist, juicy and on garlic bread.  Don't wear a tie or a shirt you really like.

Other than that, I really can't recommend the restaurant so I gave it 3 stars.  Not sure if you can give more than that to a restaurant with only one dish.

It's like the song "All Right now" - great song but can you rate Free as a great band.  Paul Rogers didn't think so, different story with Bad Company. 

Merichka's is like Free and the poorboy - a delicious one hit wonder.

Had dinner here for the first time a few nights ago  with a big group of family.  I think our entire table of 20 ordered the poor boys.  I had a poor boy as well and it was delicious!  Mushrooms, swiss cheese and their garlic butter soaking through the bread.  Delicious!
The service was a little slow, but I'm sure that's simply due to the size of our group.

We had a pretty average/below average experience. Shrimp cocktail and mushroom appetizers were good. Side salads were browning and had huge dollops of dressing forcing you to dig through sludge to get to the salad. My buddy had the pork chop, which looked good, and he confirmed it was a good dish. I had the New York Strip with 3 shrimp. The steak was tasty but the shrimp were caked in hard, bland breading. I joked with the table that I nearly broke my teeth biting into the breading. That was an exaggeration of course, but they were unusually hard. The twice baked potato was cold, and I also got bread and onion rings that I didn't taste (huge portion). My girlfriend got a filet that was overcooked. The second try was much better, but unfortunately took an additional 15 minutes and the rest of the table was finished. I don't think any of this warrants a BAD rating, but as someone that doesn't live in Joliet, I wouldn't re- visit on a return trip.

I have to be honest, the food is not  good. You're just getting a bunch of butter and garlic on your bun.    The place is old, which makes it historic. But that's really the only good thing I can say. Service is always awful.  The apple sauce is served in a container and the double baked potatoes are dry.   Seems like they are just living off of people's memories.  Oh and the prices are a bit high.

This place is the best for one reason. Po' Boys. 

If you don't like grease and heartburn then GET OUT! 

In all honesty, I've never tried anything else from here other than this sandwich. I've had it with extra garlic butter. Boy was that a ride. The typical I'd suggest is with pickles and onion.

Merichka's - 4 Stars: a nice little find on the way to Joliet. Poorboy sandwich with garlic butterene and twice baked potatoes - need I say more. I get light butterene (which request sometimes works) ... but the little strip of pounded round steak on an Italian bread roll is just perfect. Service is usually very good, the kitchen sometimes has off moments, but the food is pretty consistent and on the mark. Restaurant has lots of rooms, but since this is such a popular place there can be a wait at prime times. But go ahead and sit on one of the church pews in the waiting room and you'll be glad you did. Good for families and larger parties.

I was hopeful with such great reviews that this place was going to be amazing. It was extremely busy on a Friday night and we went for a private party. I asked everyone around me to rate their food. Everyone said it was OK but nothing to amazing. The chicken caught my eye because the serving was HUGE...everyone had chicken to take home. But everyone around me was disappointed because our friends really raved about this place...Our group also had poorboys and well I just thought it was okay. The mash potatoes were good though just a little cold. 

Maybe We didn't ordered what everyone else is ordering...but nothing stood out...not even the service (busy night?)

After hearing of Merichka's since the mid-70s, when the son of the original owner (Joe Jr?) broadcast on a Polish station for an hour on weekday evening, I finaly set foot in the door on the way back from Starved Rock.   I was surprised to learn it was still around when I saw it on Chicago's Best (Hey! Dis ain't Chicago!!) 

The steak sandwich was just awesome, and knowing that they're their own butchers tells me it's quality meat.  The onion rings were just Godly in their own rite.  I posted a photo for you!  

Loved the "old - school" charm of the place, and the waitress we had was well established, made us feel at home, and made good suggestions.
If you don't mind the smell of grease and stale beer, you might like coming here.  The food is cheap, but nothing special.  Not a place I want to go back to.

At the risk of offending native Joliet residents, Merichka's is just okay. I really like the old-timey feel of the joint, but the food could use some updating. If it weren't for the salad with house dressing and the poorboy, I wouldn't bother. Service is really good, but the food is just okay. Three stars for this Joliet classic, would rate higher if they ever try something new.

A local landmark, I love going here when I am back in town for a visit and have packed stretch pants!  The new sandwich additions look great; my husband enjoyed his chicken po- boy. However, I stick with the standard steak one.  Load me up with garlic butterine!!!  Their bar is a great place to dine as well, in a different atmosphere than the quaintly-decorated dining room.

Certainly a fixture in Crest Hill. If you are looking for a tried and true dinner experience, this could be it. Unfortunately, it is also tired and in my humble opinion, overpriced. I have friends that grew up in the area and simply love this place. However, I think there love for the place has more to do with memories versus value and quality. There are a number of better options in the area, but for the experience, you should try this at least once.

Today was my first and last time eating here.  I took my mom here for a birthday lunch.  Our server was horrible and the food was not amazing either.  I asked the waitress to describe the different breads, bun vs garlic bread and which she suggested.  She looked at me like I had three heads.  I chose the spicy fried poorboy plate.  I asked for ranch dressing on my salad, and she had me repeat myself because she thought I said merishka dressing, they don't even sound alike.  When the salad came it was swimming in dressing.  I asked her the difference between the 3 types of fries they offered, and that seemed to annoy her as well.  When she dropped the food off, I asked for ketchup and she forgot to bring it.  My sandwich was not spicy at all.  She never came back to ask how the food tasted, so I wasn't able to get my sandwich fixed.  She instead just dropped off take out boxes and the check without ever checking in.  I told her that my sandwich was not spicy but I ate half anyway because I couldn't find her to let her know it was wrong.  She looked at me again as though I was an alien and didn't even apologize.  $40 for 2 people to eat crappy food was not what we had in mind for a birthday lunch.

Having tried Filipino food a couple of times, when this popped up on Yelp near our hotel I had to go.

It's a little fancy inside, but welcoming, and I was seated quickly.  Service was great start to finish.  The menu is expansive and I was partly familiar, but the waiter stepped in with some good suggestions.  I ignored them, it turned out, but I have a feeling everything here is good.  Food came out fast.  I got the crispy binagoongan, fried pork belly with veggies.  It was a platter big enough for two, but I made a valiant effort.  The meat was perfectly cooked, and the veggies and rice (I added a side of plain) blended to make an amazing meal.  Shrimp paste, eggplant, tomatoes, onions... Just amazing flavor and textures.

Prices are very good for the quantity and quality.  There is so much on the menu I want to try.  If we are back up this way I will make more of a dent.

Went with a friend who never tasted a Filipino food and he was pleased. We ordered Lechon Kawali, Chicken Adobo, Seafood Karekare, Bowl of Garloc Fried Rice, and Halo halo. All were good and tasty. Unfortunately the fish paste for the Seafood Karekare was not within our like of sight and hidden behind the huge bowl of Karekare so we ate without it; I wished we would've known as I don't normally eat this dish. It was bland and my friend agreed given to what was mentioned, we wished it was on plain sight. Lechon Kawali was great and crunchy, though the sauce was the generic liver sauce (Mang Tomas) nothing special there.

The server was great and suggested some for us and we tried it, such as ordering a bowl of rice instead of 3 cups of rice. Thank you for that. But once we ate, we were only checked one time and we had to get the attention of other servers so we can ask for something. Observing the servers, there was a lot of talking amongst themselves and that could be one reason why we weren't paid good attention, also it would be appreciated if all of them smiled and not look that they were having a bad day or just had a poker face. Our main server was great though he smiled genuinely and had good mannerism. What's good was after we got their attention, our request was granted in a timely manner, it wasn't a hectic day I might add.

This was our first time coming here. We're from the Chicago city area so it was a drive to get here.. 

I'd give this place a 2.5 only because the food was great but the service was really bad.. 
Maybe it was the time that we got here (around 2:30 on a Sunday) but the service was just... bad. First off, there was a really disorganized line - only one line for both those waiting to be seated AND for to go orders. Everyone was hovering the front desk and customers were all over the place.   As I waited in line, I noticed waiters on the side talking rather than cleaning up tables  for other customers to be seated. 
Anyways, they finally called our names and we were seated an hour later. They took our order (hototai soup, crispy pata, pancit Bihon, okoy, Kare kare, and 3 desserts - halo halo, Taho, and buko pandan - & like I said we came from Chicago so we wanted to try a lot of food and take whatever left home). We got our food in decent time and everything was fresh and hot (which is why I'd give this a 4/5 if only rating the quality of the food)..
BUT.... Honestly there was a lot of hair on the crispy pata - not appealing at all. And the pancit came last and we were basically done with all our main dishes by the time it came out (we thought they'd forgotten about the order). But whatever, it was good. 

SO THEN they eventually gave us the check.. YET it turned out to be someone else's check smh (theirs was like 90 and ours was supposed to be around 60) so we complained and they finally came back with our check. We paid, blah blah. BUT WHERES OUR DESSERTS? A bus boy kept hovering our table like wondering why we aren't leaving and we finally told him that we've been waiting for our 3 desserts for the past 10 minutes after we returned our check. So they finally give us the halo halo and Taho and they apologize for the wait and thank us.. BUT WHERES THE BUKO PANDAN? So they finally give us that after like 5 minutes... Smh everything was just going badly service wise. 


Other than the terrible service the food was pretty good especially because it's rare to find a Filipino restaurant that doesn't have oil overpowering the food. Also, the quality and quantity of the food was fair for the price. The food is the reason I gave this place a 2 (a 2.5 if I could) but the service was too bad for me to give it any more.

I actually really like this place. I'll admit it- I tend to be skeptical about Filipino restaurants because my mom caters Filipino food and I haven't found a place that is up to par with her cooking until Hong Ning. I recommend! My mom does too!

We usually visit on Sunday afternoons. There is always a bit of a wait, but we just walk over to the nearby Starbucks to kill time (the waiting area is not that big). From my experience, the wait never went over 30 minutes for a group of 4. Most of the guests come in families. 

The decor is nice, but the floor is a bit slippery-- not sure why. The tables are small, especially since the food comes in large plates/platters so the table gets a bit crowded once the food comes. I can tell that this place is a bit understaffed, but service was still pretty good on all occasions we've been there. All servers are helpful, despite how much they are running back and forth from the kitchen to the dining area. 

We always order the sinigang, crispy pata, and the inihaw fiesta. The entrees are meant to be shared, so the portions are a bit large for 2 people. 

Sinigang: Yum! Served at a nice, hot temperature and is very sour-- which is how I like my sinigang. It could've had more meat and veggies, but it is still very good. 

Crispy Pata: We order a large for a group of 4 of us. Very crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. They got the dipping sauce right, too. 

Inihaw Fiesta: Beautiful presentation, it's served on a platter with banana leaves (love!). It comes with muscles, calamari, tilapia, barbecue chicken skewers, chargrilled pork belly, dipping sauce, and bagoong. This is perfect for a larger group. Definitely my favorite on the menu. 

Overall: I very much recommend! Honestly, Hong Ning is the ONLY Filipino restaurant in the Chicago-land area that my family and I regularly visit. Haven't found another restaurant that we like enough to make a second/third visits to except this place!

I came here on one of my Friday lunch outings. I really like Filipino food because it reminds me of the friends.i made in college. However, the restaurant didn't have a lot on their lunch special. I ordered off the main menu and I think the food was a little costly. Also, for lunch, this was not a good option. We had an hour to eat but the check took a while. The food I got was good, but not a huge favorite. I think if you want authentic meats like tripe, oxtail and jackfruit, come here. They have a lot of those options.

I've gone here since I was a kid, and although I think the owner is amazing and has worked so hard to make this place as successful as it is, he needs to do something about his waitstaff. They seem blas and unfocused. Upon seating, our party of 5 was given as carafe of ice water... with no glasses. I asked waiter #1 for cups. He said yes, then proceeded to do other various tasks. 5 min later I ask waiter #2 for cups. She says yes.. then a couple min later, waiter #3 arrives with our cups. But in all that time no one asked if we were ready to order. We finally order (15 min after being seated), and the food arrives very quickly. The amount of stars I've given are based on the food alone. I've never had any bad food here. Maybe the negative food reviews are on their off days?

So we finish what we can but of course have leftovers. I went through the same amount of almost begging for to go containers as well as the check. When asking for the containers the 2nd time, I also asked for our 2 halo halo to go, since at that point I just wanted to get out of there. It took almost 30 minutes from the time I asked for the check the 1st time to the time I could finally leave. 

I'm not sure if I've done something to offend the waitstaff but it definitely felt that way. I'll definitely be back, but never again to stay and dine in. I hope they improve their ideals of what it means to be customer-oriented. You don't have to love your job to deal with the public, you just have to know how to make the customers believe you do. ;)

Went two times in the last two days. 

The interior is really nice. Enough to take guests when they come or for a fancier outing consisting of Filipino deliciousness. 

First time the service was A+, but the second day it was so slow...they also forgot to give us rice as our entrees were coming out and one of our dishes came out as we finished our food. We ended up sending it back because it was too late. But everything we ate was delicious, so I am less bitter. 

Recommended Dishes:
Seafood KareKare 
Fried Tilapia 
Fried, Marinated Milkfish 
Garlic rice 

The desserts were worth the try and really good: 
Halo Halo 
Taho 
Flan

Want to try next time: 
Chicken Adobo 
A soup dish

Fact 1: The Philippines has over 7000 islands, is the second most polylingual nation on earth after Papua New Guinea and cuisine-wise is as varied and diverse as the cultures that have influenced it from the Spanish to the Chinese to the American, et al. 

Fact 2: despite being proud of the awesomely diverse culture, just about every Pinoy/Pinay dining at a Filipino restaurant secretly expects the food coming out of the kitchen to taste EXACTLY like mom's, lola's or tita's.

Fact 3. Ain't no way a Pinoy/Pinay that is dining w mom, lola or tita will admit that the restaurant food is better. That would be suicide.

Given these undisputed facts, it is a testament of quality to Hong Ning that they've been able to thrive for almost 2 decades from its original humble store front in Glendale Heights to its current locale in an area that has a large Filipino community full of home cooks that think they're the latest incarnation of Iron Chef Pilipinas. Hong Ning has stood the test of time bc it's good Filipino food period. If you don't like the food here, you might just not appreciate Filipino food. Yet. Give it a few tries before you give up bc sometimes people need some adjusting to unfamiliar flavors.

Anyhow, if you haven't tried Filipino food, this is a great place to start. The food here is better than some nationally recognized Filipino spots I've been to around the country. Entrees are inexpensive and I suggest coming with a group of at least 4+ so you can try a lot of things (BBQ!). The service I've had here has been above average especially for an Asian restaurant (no shade thrown... You know what I mean!) and especially since the last time I was here it was with a rowdy group of 20+ picky ass eaters who ditched their moms, lolas and titas bc they didn't want to hide the fact that they were really enjoying the food. A lot.

Hong Ning has upgrade their location!  I can't believe they have been around for almost 20 years.  The decor is very nice and the restaurant is spacious.  This is where Vietnamese Bistro used to be and hopefully Hong Ning can make it last.  There aren't many choices nearby by for Filipino food, so any location is a good location.

Hototai Soup $7 - Clear broth easy to eat soup
Kamansi $9
Mixed Chicken and Pork Adobo $10 - One of my favorite dishes here.  Savory and delicious.
Large Rice $3

Great food presentation and place is clean.  It is located in a not so busy stripmall. Overall look is similar to a school cafeteria except that someone takes your order and serves the food at your table. Servings were ok but pricetag was a bit high for the general ambiance. 
Don't be misled by the chinese sounding name though- this serves Filipino food.

Terrible service. I asked for a pitcher of water, the waiter said yes but didn't come back, so I looked back to where all the waitstaff was standing and he was freaking sitting!  Our original waitress was sort of in a daze, and did not come back to ask how the food was; and to think it wasn't even packed in the restaurant. The way I was treated in "American/Italian restaurants" was far better, even with the fact that I'm Filipino. 

They have good food and I have been here thrice  but because of their service today, it took away the joy of enjoying our meal.

Certainly will not travel 30 miles again to be treated this way.
Awesome place to get Filipino food! Food is served hot with decent portions. Love this place!

Our first time at the new location.  Kind of far for us, but the food was delicious.  We had very low expectations of the staff, and were thus not disappointed.  They gave us pitchers of water, so we did not need to hunt anyone down to refill our glasses.  

We ordered the calamari (skip it - huge rubbery rings of seafood), lechon roll (lots of fat, but the meat and skin were crispy and tasty), kare-kare (plenty of beef cubes, but I prefer it with more oxtail and more sauce), a pancit (a bit salty), a grilled chicken, halo halo (yum!), and a pandan sundae (very good!).  See photos.

We tried to call for a reservation, but were told it was strictly first come - first served.  Luckily, we were seated right away.  When we left, there was a line out the door!  Go early or go on a weekday!

Food is incredible! One of my favorite spots in the burbs. If you like crispy pata get it here! Make sure you act quick though. They sell out fast! The dishes hit close to home. Keep up the great work!

We are proud of this Filipino restaurant to which we have taken many guests. Ever since they moved to this Carol Stream location they upgraded the entire dining experience. Not only is the food still delicious with generous servings and nicely presented, but the staff is younger and friendly. The Filipino decor on the east wall is tastefully done, and you can learn about Philippine history and culture by taking a close look. Good quality tables and chairs are not usual at Asian restaurants, so I am glad they invested in them. But my #1 pet peeve with Asian restaurants is the typical filthy, icky restrooms and the hallways that lead to them. Hong Ning has now broken ranks from that low standard and have installed presentable, decorated restrooms that are clean! May they keep it up!

I've been going to the old location since forever but something about this new location just somehow made Hong Ning 100 times better. the art work was beautifully displayed and the vibe of the restaurant from the food to the furniture (tables/benches) really made me feel at home. I truly felt like I was eating a home cooked meal in the Philippines with each bite of every dish.  everything was beautifully prepared and the food was great. Come by if you're missing some authentic Filipino food and dessert. 

also, staff was very polite and helpful! 

will be back again
Have to drive an hour for this place, they have the best, tastiest halo halo ever ... and their crispy binagoongan makes you feel happy.Looking forward to come back to this place.

5 stars for the food, but 4 stars overall due to their service. This is one of the better filipino restaurants that serves really well cooked filipino food. The crispy lupia is cooked to perfection. Perfect crunch with a meaty inside. I recommend to skip the calamare. It used to be fried squid, but now its the rubbery squid rings that you can get a a grocery store. The chicken inasal with java rice dish is one of my favorite dish. It comes with about 4 chicken medium sized chicken breast grilled well. Inside is moist and tender. My family likes to get the Crispy pata, which is roasted pork hock. Skin is crunchy and there is a lot of fat, but the meat is tender. 
This place gets pretty busy, so if you come with a party make sure you have everyone with you, or they won't sit you. Service wise, kind of typical of any asian place, you usually have to flag down a server and they tend to be inattentive and slow. Don;t worry if its not the one that initially served you. Flagged down any of the staff that is running around so you can get what you need.

Living away from home, I'm always looking for a good Filipino restaurant. This is the best I've had so far in the Chicagoland area. Lumpia Shanghai almost as good as Mom's. Inihaw na liempo, calderetta, lechon kawali, all so good. Must take the trip from the city to eat here!

I tried this placed well over a decade ago when it was still at their old location. Back then I was far from impressed. Perhaps it was my food selection  (I honestly can't remember what it was that I had ordered). This evening I decided to give it another shot not feeling like preparing anything at home and knowing my rather picky son would settle at the very least with some white rice and something crunchy. I decided on something rather simple that both my little sons would be happy with. We ordered the shanghai egg rolls, BBQ pork skewers and an order of chicken inasal. The chicken in particular was very good. My boys were happy and couldn't get enough of their baby egg rolls. My 4yr old (the particular one ) asked me about 4 times if we were going to be able to bring the egg rolls home... so that means they were a hit, lol. He was not excited to eat there on the way to dinner but made sure to ask me on our car ride home if we could go back sometime. We'll be back and I'm excited to try something else soon. Service was fine. They weren't overly attentive but available when I needed something so I have no complaints with regards to service.

I went here with my grandfather and uncle for supper on a Wednesday night. The waitress was really nice and patient with me as I totally mispronounced several names of items on the menu.

We ordered okoy, lumpia shanghai, fresh wrapper lumpia, pancit bihon, crunchy bagoonan, chicken adobo, lechon and garlic rice. Everything was delicious.

I really loved the lechon! We also had flan, pandan sundae and halo halo. If you are looking for filipino food, I definitely recommend Hong Ning.
Came in on a hot summer day.  I knew what I was going to order before I walked in.  Best Halo-Halo I've had at a restaurant in years!

Sizzling bangus belly was really good! Sauce was tasty and not too strong. We got sited within a few minutes of waiting. We were handed menus while waiting. Although we were asked multiples times how many we were in the group. And by different people. Place is very family oriented.

I come here all the time, as the location is near my parents' house. The food is good, but the service is slow! It took a while for our server to get to our table. We ask for napkins, then they leave and take a long time to come back. Same thing at the end, when we ask for the check. 

The food is delicious, but only when it's available! We order fresh lumpia, but they are often out of stock and will cancel orders in the middle of your meal. They also adjust or cancel to-go orders when their supply is low, but they don't even call customers to let them know that the order is being changed. One time, I ordered a large pata, only for it to be downsized to a small. I didn't find out until I arrived to pick up my order.

The restaurant gets loud when there are a lot of people, as the floor and walls are not designed to absorb sound.

I give this place 4.
5 stars for the food which were all good: dinuguan, pancit, lechon, 
I give 3 stars for the service.  Our order was taken shortly after we got seated.  We didn't have to wait long for our food, but our waiter wasn't the greatest. He wasn't smiling, he never checked on us, we had to flag people down for help with getting containers and our checks.

Good food, slow service but not as bad as previous customers made it out to be. 

We started with a hearty bowl of lomi soup which is made with thick pancit rice noodles, assorted meat, and a beef gravy. Warmed the bones on a cold fall day. 

We moved on to  the salted fish & chicken fried rice and 3 sticks of chicken barbecue a la cart. The fried rice is my favorite! 

Good value for the price. We have leftovers for lunch the next few days. Definitely coming back again.

The food are fantastic! Been coming here every weekend for 2 months now. We try different food every time we order. My hubby favorite are pork sinigang, caldereta and sisig. Mine is halo halo to go. But for some reason that I still want more in halo halo. Some taste that I have been looking for it. Please work on it. ..
The service was good. The food arrived so fast, but the juice come at the end. But it's ok.

Service is too slow, we got seated and ignored for 20 mins! When the waitress finally came , she asked if we ordered already. I was about to walk out when she said that , but I was still being nice because the old Hong Ning was very good. We ordered sizzling tangigue (king fish) , it was awful. Too dry and very oily, the fish was not fresh at all. Also ordered the pork bbq and it tasted "funny". The shrimp was oily and very salty. After our meal we still waited for freakin 30 mins for our server to check up on us if we are done, I saw her in the back sitting , talking and laughing at her co workers. I finally called a different waiter for our bill. I would never go back there ever again, the old Hong Ning was good but not this place!

Came at Hong ning for the first time. Since we heard it from other filipinos that this place is good. Me and my fiancee came here for the first time last night for dinner, and immediatle the place doesn't look like your typical filipino restaurant. The decor is very nice the tables and lighting are unique. When we got in the place is packed and busy with filipino athmosphere.. We were seated right away after they cleaned a table for us. 

The menu was very simple and right on the spot your classic filipino dishes. We started with appetizer of fried calamri and for entree the sizzling sisig and grilled pork belly. The service was fast, food came in quickly.. 

The food is very flavorful and everything we like. The only negative was they charge for the rice.

For dessert we ordered the halo halo. And it was plentiful for the price me and fiancee had hard time tackling it. 

Overall our 1hr trip was all worth the drive. They set the standards high for all filipino restaurants. Filipino restaurant in the orland park area are pretty mediocre. 

We will be back soon. If we crave for more filipino food.

I am glad I chose to visit this place without consulting the Yelp reviews.  I feel obligated to detail our lunch, and our experience which is not (at least as of this date) reflected in the restaurant's current rating.  Lunch - crazy good.  We had a garlic rice, which I must learn how to recreate, as it was insanely good.  I did the adobo chicken and my lunch partner/nephew did a fried pork belly dish with shrimp paste.  Holy cow, it was all so good.  Service was splendid.  I have tried to come here twice before but the line/wait was too long and I gave up.  I am so glad we did lunch, and I will be back again, probably this week.

Food is very good tasting, they cook it as you order. We love the food here that is why we keep coming back even though the wait to get seated always takes very long and service always tales very long too. Staff is not very well trained but they are helpful.

I've been here a few times and love it. I've never had a single bad experience here. 

If you've never had Filipino food it may be best to stick to the skewers and rice which by the way taste just as good as the skewers you can by on the street in Manila  or Makati. 

I highly recommend this place if your looking for some terrific Filipino food!

Update review: Decided to give it another try. So what changed?
1. They now have a hostess in the front receiving! 
2. The waitress asked us about our drink preference and menu selection within 5 minutes upon seated. 
3. This time, we were able to eat! 

We ordered Lomi, Calamares, Crispy Pata, and Kare Kare. 
Our group had fun especially we chose HongNing to celebrate my husbands Birthday.

I'm not sure how I feel about giving them 2 stars, but I am willing to give them another try...another time and hopefully it will bump it up a little. And it is also my first time having Filipino food, and I was so disappointed. 

I've never been to the old location, but this one is spacious and the decor is interesting. When you first walk in, it smells delicious and you can't wait to sit down and order.

I had ordered a kare kare. It is a braised oxtail and tripe in a "peanut sauce." First off, there were no "peanut" present in the sauce whatsoever. like none. The tripe were big pieces and uncut, so it is a little chewy to bite. They were also not cleaned well, therefore  it gave off a fishy smell. The oxtail were okay, the meat fell right off the bone so it was easy to eat. Overall, the dish was very bland and under flavored. It looked like a curry, and I was hoping it would taste like the sort..but it didn't.

My boyfriend got the pritong  tilapia, basically it is just a WHOLE tilapia deep fried. They also served it with their "house spiced vinegar." The fish... was fishy. Because it was not rubbed in any spice or flavoring, the fish was very fishy. Their sauce seemed like it was just soy sauce mixed with vinegar because there were no "spice" to it. 

Our meal was served with rice and some sort of fish or shrimp paste. I have eaten my fair share of fish and shrimp paste. I mean, Vietnamese people know how to ferment their shit man. I digress, anyways...the smell of that paste was so pungent. The taste was delicious to the bland meal, but I could not get over that smell. I did not find it very pleasant. 

I am also wary at the fact that they CHARGED me for rice, like really? RICE for crying out loud. 

I was not impressed with this place, seeing how many of my Filipino friends boasted about this place and how salty Filipino food can be and how EVERYTHING was delicious. smh.

New location at Carol Stream: spacious and looks clean; Filipino Decors on the wall give a nice touch of nationalism. 
Food: We came for lunch on a weekday to avoid the weekend crowd. We ordered pretty much the main traditional dishes: crispy pata, beef soup, pata tim, fried rice, halo-halo, kare-Kare, pinaputok na bangus.  The servings were satisfactory. But overall, the food lacks flavor, the meats could be more tender, and needs more time for flavor to set in. The pata tim was one of my greater disappointments -- the hocks tasted gamey, and wasn't cleaned/shaved well of pig's  hair. Kare Kare was tough, and lacks the usual creamy flavor of the dish. Fried rice was ... A little on the hard side.  The owner was around talking to a few patrons, said Hi to us at the beginning but never came around again. If he had taken the time to ask us about the food, we would have told him.

Hmm lets shed some light into the 4-5star rating by some of the "Filipino" yelpers. I don't write many Yelp Reviews unless it's the best thing or the worst thing I ever ate OR unless it really pissed me off...LOL...If you like salty very salty Filipino food and lack of service this is the place to be. I ordered the "sizzling pusit" and there was nothing sizzling about it literally... It was cold and it was NOT cleaned properly it's was sandy and I had a plastic cartilage that needed to be taken out!  

We're not the only one that noticed the salt,the family behind us said the same thing about the food they ordered which solidify my findings.

Then the Caldereta came short rib style and the meat was not tender... It needed about 30 more minutes in the pressure cooker! Caldereta needs a little more spice! The only saving grace to my first experience here was the Lechon Roll that's it. I hate that they charge for white rice! Even the Chinese people don't do that no offense... But it's true! 

If you want authentic Filipino food try Sarilin Atin in Des Plaines! It's a small hole in a wall place but their weekend buffet is grand slam I can't say anything bad about them.  Again it's a really small place but it's a hidden gem..I just wish I lived closer to Des Plaines so I can go there everyday. 

In conclusion if you want to pay extra for rice, lack of customer service, and an insane amount of salt then Hong NiNg is the place to be... Sorry Yelpers I must have missed the memo on this one...
I came here for the first time and the last time, the  people work here are very rude! Especially the host lady!

This restaurant is very unprofessional! As the customers I walk in and stand right a front of the receptionist booth! I stand there for a good 5 minute without a greeting, beside that I have to listen the native language between 2 hostess! I try to say hello to them but I never get a chance cuz they never stop talking , they are very rude!i don't care how good the food is! But with the bad start service like that I don't I will enjoy the food!

Frankly, I'm surprised by the bad reviews of this place.  Either we went on an extraordinary night, or those who didn't like this place have never eaten at a "real" Filipino restaurant.  Most of the bad reviews spoke of bad service or finding hairs on food.  Granted, we weren't cowtowed to in Hong Ning as we've been in snootier places that we enjoyed half as much, but I had no service complaints and the food was fantastic.

Which is another thing: many reviewers weren't impressed with the food.  Again, maybe we went on a night where the best chef from the Philippines was substituting for the regular guy... but somehow I doubt it.  My guess is that either Chicagoans are pampered by the only really great Filipino restaurants in America and are therefore spoiled, or they don't know Filipino food at all.

I have eaten at many a Pinoy restaurant, both here in LA and in various locations in the Philippines, and the only place in which I have eaten that comes close to the wonderful food I had on Luzon and Palawan was right here at Hong Ning.  Now the review.

I was in the mood for pork in a big way, and with Pilipino food that almost always means fatty pork belly.  We had the liempo, the crispy pata, lechon and sisig to satisfy that urge (and then some); in addition we sampled the pancit and chicken inasal.  Everything was delicious.  The pata was divinely crispy but not crunchy; the liempo was tangy, saucy and tasty; the lechon had thin, crisp, succulent skin and tender yet juicy meat with appropriately light seasoning and the sisig was the best I've had outside of the Philippines, even if it wasn't made from a pig's head (as is traditional and fantastic, for my likewise ignorant American friends).  The pancit bihon was just fine (I've had better, but that was in Tayabas) and the chicken inasal was unexpectedly tasty: delicate seasoning so as not to overwhelm the flavor of the chicken, and the single large breast we received was unusually juicy and tender for grilled chicken.  I couldn't do better myself--and I'm a damn good cook!

This is a good place for Whities like me to introduce themselves to Pinoy foods (a thing I strongly recommend for those planning on visiting the Philippines, or those who just love good food and to say hell with the calories), mainly because everyone working here speaks English.  If you expect 5-star service, go to some snobbish French bistro for inferior food and the ass kissing you require.  Regular folks will like it here just fine.

Came to this restaurant a week ago Sunday.  The food was tasty, the ambiance was themed, and the people were super nice.  I cheated, as I knew what to order as I have Filipino friends, and they told me what to get.

Let me tell you, if your coming here, i would highly recommend that you only order 1 appetizer, we ordered 2, and were stuffed before the entrees arrived.

Great food, warm environment, and friendly service.  Price was good.

I will definitely be back again.
Delicious food, hospitable servers and an inviting and spacious venue. Loved the ethnic decor and the friendly staff!

im sure the food is good when hot...  but Christ the service is SLOOOOW!!!!!   Come on guys get a clue....  get it together.  im a fan of the food (being filipino and the closet filipino resto in the area)...  but hello...  pay attention to the customers and speed things up and turn those tables!!!!!

fyi your salted egg and tomato salad....  very disappointing!!!
We go eat here at least 2 times a month never disappointed with the food. Best Filipino I have had.

You don't find a lot of Filipino restaurants around the suburbs.. This one is a good find.. Food is awesome.. One of the servers tend to be so rude but I noticed he's nice to regulars.. STILL GOING BACK tho.. :)

I wanted to order food for lunch and just pick it up and go. I asked if they could fax me a menu with the prices and they said no. We also asked if we could order in advance and pick it up and they said no. It took me 45 minutes from my office, go there, order food and go back to the office.  They definitely were not very accommodating. 
We get back to work and share the food with co-workers who have had Filipino food before.  I asked them how they would rate the food and their response was......... we've had better and the food was very bland. It wasn't as good as what I expected it to be after reading some reviews and watching the video.  Over all I would rate their food a 4 out of 10.

I have been making the drive to Hong Ning for the past year and living in the northern suburbs it is quite a drive. The first time we made our way there, they forgot three orders. The second time, we waited for a halo halo that was never to come. I just don't know why my wife likes the food here but to each his own taste I guess. Previous reviews state the lack of attention of the servers to the customers which I kept pointing out to my wife. The servers are just "aloof". They just don't understand that if they don't take care of the business, they just might end up looking for another job. My wife is thinking of trying the new place and I'm still in the process of trying to change her mind. Best of luck to the owner who doesn't seem to care about customer service.

I was planning on going here with a group of 12 people.  I was in the neighborhood days before so decided to stop in to try some lumpia - Filipino staple, right? OMG, this was the worst lumpia I ever had!  And after I asked for lumpia, the server was like eggrolls?!?! Seriously it was like a lumpia hot dog  The inside of the lumpia was like they took all the ingredients, pureed them and then stuffed them back into the lumpia rolls then cut them into two inch pieces.  Now I know lumpia.  I am Filipino. I make my own lumpia at home.  This was SO disappointing because the place itself was really nice on the inside, had a nice crowd of people.  But if the lumpia was this bad and this processed, I couldn't go back and try the rest of their food. However the gulaman sago was good. Only reason I gave two stars.

My co-worker and I came to this restaurant for lunch - we were planning to go to the China Chef next door, but since we knew we hadn't tried Hong Ning we wanted to give it try.  Totally wrong idea. We got in about 12:15 and got seated.  Realized lunch menu was not given to us, so we asked our server to bring.  He was extremely slow - took more than 5 minutes to bring the menu itself.  Ordered two of the lunch menu and then we were told that one of them was ALREADY out of it.  It was only 15-20 minutes past from noon, plus, the seats were not full at all.  We had no choice but ordered two of the same lunch menu.  Then only 1 of 2 came.  We waited another 10 minutes or so, and finally they brought another one. It took eventually about 45 minutes for us to start eating together, and we of course were running out of time.  We had a couple of bites then had to leave.  Some parties of 4-5 people were served fully before us although they came in later than us. The lunch menu - pork was good but no vegetable in it, just pork and garlic rice.  It was not really special anyway, or I have to say, their poor customer service really made everything screwed up. I don't think I want to visit there again.

If you go here, you'll need a lot of time. The first time I tried this place I showed up after to just open it and it was really busy. I waited for about an hour and a half before they actually finally got my order out and it was wrong. About an hour into my wait they finally told me they didn't have some of my order so I had yo wait longer. I didn't go back for a while because I thought they needed time to adjust to a new building and I assumed they would've fix this problem.  Tonight I called in an order just a simple order of lumpia. They told me a time of 20 minutes. I showed up 20 minutes later and after 10 minutes of waiting for them to finally acknowledge me at the front door they let me know that they hadn't started the order yet. He made a joke about them forgetting to put it in. I told them not to bother. Reading the other reviews shows me it wasn't an isolated issue. I'm sure the food is tasty. But the one time I ate it, it tasted like spite so I'll avoid it from now on. There are plenty of restaurants around that are concerned for their customers and show it.
Food is super greasy, fatty, and loaded with a lot of MSG! Restaurant is clean though as it is newer. Food quality is ok, nothing special.
I hate to do this, the food was ok. But two human hairs in two different things is too many. Never again.

Excellent Lithuanian food in a small location that does both dine-in and carry-out. Prompt & friendly service, and the dining room, front counter, and bathrooms are kept clean. The combo platter is a good choice for 2-4 people who are looking for the classics (kugelis, sausage, cepelinai, etc.). Went in a group of 4, and we all agree that this place beats Grand Dukes. We thought it was worth the trip and will definitely be coming back to this restaurant! :)

While we were dining at Ruta yesterday I kept telling my wife we needed to check the kitchen because I thought my grandmother might be back there. 

She wouldn't check for me. She doesn't like to join me on my misadventures. But that's not the point.

This place has the best kugelis I've eaten since my grandma died. Well, I've made a pretty decent batch myself once or twice, but this place still does it better, and more authentic I would imagine too.

We tried koldunai, kugelis and cepelinai. The latter which I would not recommend unless you've had it before. I kind of hate them, but most Lithuanians do not feel the same way. I'm broken, I guess. I think they're gluey and tasteless. 

However, they're very authentic, because I never liked my grandma's either. So if you want the real deal, get your Lugan butt over to Ruta!
Service horrible, food - so so, interior poor, cold inside. Truly said- I'll never come again.

Company ordered from here for lunch and as far as they can tell me... They gave it 10 stars for authenticity! Their food is very filling so don't worry if you're not ordering too enough. You gotta try their fried bread salad. It's kind of like a rye croutons tossed with veggies and cheese. 

Why are their dishes so filling? Because most of their dishes are made with grated potatoes and sort of dehydrated, then PACKED. Now that's a lot of potato. 

Unfortunately, I'm not a fan of too much sour cream. Next time I order anything, I'll have to ask them to keep it on the side instead globbing it next to my dish for me.

Again, why is this listed under BBQ? haha

It is a nice little nook, I have come here on occasion after biking at Waterfall Glen in the summer or when I need a change of scenery while studying.
It is a nice, quiet environment with a beautiful color scheme. The place is never very full so it is a nice, relaxing atmosphere. There is also a really nice outside sitting area for warmer weather.

The service I have had has always been fantastic. I have always had the same tall, dark-haired.

The coffee is good. Nothing breath-taking, in my opinion, but I would choose this over Starbucks any day of the week!

I have only ever had the crepes, meat and fruit, when I have come here. I wasn't too impressed with the fruit ones, the fruit never seemed so fresh, but the plate was decorated so nicely. I like the meat ones though, but perhaps that is my German coming out! 
I am more used to the French-style of crepes, thinner and crispier than the crepes at Ruta, so it is an interesting texture and heartier.

The only thing that could really be improved upon is the menu. Yes, I do like that is in English and Lithuanian; but it is not descriptive at all.
For example, with the meat crepes I was taking a bit of a gamble. There was no description of what kind of meat, spices, flavor, etc. So luckily it turned out well!

First off I have NO CLUE why this place is listed under Barbeque Restaurants Breakfast & Brunch Barbeque. 

Ok I was HAPPY to see a Lithuanian restaurant SO close to my house. My father is part Lithuanian so I am familiar with some of the foods. Yummo!! 

I thought they gave BIG portions for a great low price!! I don't think there was anything over $10.00. The waitress we had was nice. It is in a little strip mall off of Cass Avenue. Clean, simple interior. Small place but it was nice and quiet when I went for lunch. 

I like how their menu is in English and in Lithuanian. Pretty cool! :)

I will def give them another go when I am not watching my carbs.

Waitress sweet, attentive and very helpful with menu selections.  I had pork cutlet with mushrooms and husband had chicken with bread sticks. Both perfectly cooked and flavorful.  Startled with spinach soup.  Broth based with spinach, light dill, potato, some egg and garnished with sour cream.  Very flavorful and hearty portion when you enjoyed the light rye bread and butter.  Loved the entree plate which had beet salad, coleslaw, sliced tomatoes and cucumber curls as a side dish plus the broasted potatoes.  Was pretty plus tasted really good. Even the husband loved the coleslaw and the beet salad!  Finished with a ball of pastry that had farmer's cheese in it.  She called it something like a patchkee?  Bought two to go and ate them as soon as we got home because we couldn't help ourselves.  Didn't know Lithuanian food was so good.  Will definitely return.

I came here a few months ago to meet my brother and niece for lunch. I work in Aurora, and he lives in Oswego, so it seemed to be right in the middle for us. I didn't know that this was takeout only, but that's fine, we can eat in our car. The menu is somewhat confusing, but everything we got was great. I got the fried Philly cheese steak, which I have never even tried/had before. It came out piping hot, and was delicious. Not overly greasy. The fries were good. My niece got the chicken fingers, and she chowed them down. It was made fresh, with nothing sitting under warmers having been premade. The only con was the dessert. We love Red Velvet cake and decided to try a slice. They do get it from an out of house bakery, but that was the worst piece of Red Velvet cake we had ever had. Luckily, my little niece didn't seem to mind. I would go back here to eat again.

Yep, fried chicken available. Nondescript flavor that actually tastes better at room temperature. 

You deal directly with the owner who makes it perfectly clear that you must order from the menu. No deviation allowed. Definitely not a customer service afficienado.

The overhead menu is a confusing mess of numbers that's actually a distraction. Your allowed 6 pieces of these, only if you get 12 of those. Your taste buds scream for 4 of those, as long as you order 10 of these. However, if you order 20 of those...it comes with fries.

If you want it "your way" go elsewhere!

Stopped in here today on a whim.

The Chicken Coop is a no-frills take-out place with a diverse menu of chicken, fish, and gyro options. I decided to try to catfish sandwich (despite not liking catfish - I have no idea why I decided to try it) and got my wife an Gyro.

The catfish sandwich was tasty and I would definitely order it again in the future. The fry of the fish was perfect, the lettuce, tomato, and onions were all very obviously fresh, and the tzatziki sauce I asked for on the side was an awesome complement to it. I was pleasantly surprised.

My wife had me try a piece of meat from her gyro and it was fantastic. Having lived in Buffalo, NY and personally believing that Buffalo has some of the best foods available in the United States, this gyro was good enough for me to call it "Buffalo-good."

It's a little pricier than I expected but I will definitely be returning. Next time I'll try the wings and maybe a different kind of fish. My wife? She'll be getting a gyro, I'm sure. It was just that amazing.
Catfish is very good!  Ask for extra crispy..  Kitchen is not fancy but clean and they cook to order.  Ordered several times and it's consistent..

Yeah, here's the prime example of a place that looks like a shithole, in a kind of deserted location that serves great food.
I expected to find a roach-palace, but the interior is very clean, and actually inviting once you get inside. the Menu is a little bewildering at first, but give it a second and you'll make sense out of it. It's a classic Chicago take-out joint! (nowhere to sit and eat inside at all)
Mostly fried everything. And they do it well. REALLY well!
I've had a bunch of the menu, and everything had that GOOD fresh fried flavor. This guy takes pride. Have NOT had any of the non-fried stuff like the Hotdog or Burger, so I can't comment on those. I don't think those are the things you come to this joint for. But based on the rest of the menu, I'll bet the remainder of stuff this guy serves will be fine.
DO look for the special combo handwritten in the ordering area-you can get three or four entree items with Fries for a decent price. Some chicken, Some fish and some shrimp (among other items) A great little sampler. And they have Livers and Gizzards! You can see right into the kitchen. Gotta love it when nothing is hidden at all!
The plates are bursting with food, and the only hassle I've had coming here was the Foam Clamshells popping open in the bag on the way home 'cos there was too much food stuffed in them! Such a Problem!!
Everything is made a la minute, so you're going to have a little wait after you order. That wait is worth it.

Best fried wings around.  The hotsauce is good too.  Keep intending on tryin something different but cant stay away from the wings.
Would of given 5 stars but owner constantly on phone while servicing me which is a little annoying

So glad i found this place.
If you're looking for some good Catfish and Fried Chicken, this is the place.
Everything I've had is fresh and made to order.
The owner & his wife are supper friendly and the place is clean.

Take out only
I like this place. We get the chicken and it's great. I think the owner seems nice and polite. The prices recently went up and I don't like that. But overall it's a good place.

Horrible horrible horrible food and customer service!!!!!!!! Ordered 2 Gyro's and 2 pizza puffs with fries and cheese sauce and it cost $24. The gyros had burnt meat and not to mention there was more tomatoes than meat. The fries had no salt and the pizza puffs were also burnt. I asked him to remake the food and he said no because there was nothing wrong with the food. He refused to give me my money back and called the police on me. The guy was so rude and racist lied to the police saying my husband was threatening him. I don't know how he stays in business.  I should've went to Mr Beef and Gyro's down the street. Will never go back.

Wow! The chicken here is so TENDER and FLAVORFUL!  I wish I would've stopped here when they opened last year! Great tasting chicken at affordable prices, The Chicken Coop is my spot from now on!!  I haven't even tried their fish yet! If it's as good as the chicken I'm in trouble! LOL! Come check this place out, I promise you won't be disappointed!!

A fun Snow White-themed restaurant, with old world / old school charm.

The restaurant is basically a family diner with lots of Snow White and dwarf themed paintings and nick-knacks. Fun, but not leaving a great impression like a theme park.

The food and service were solid. I tried a chili taco salad (not sure why, just struck me as fun) and it was pretty standard in flavor, though a very generous portion. I had a side of dumpling soup, which was OK. Fun dumplings, and decent flavor, served piping hot. The bread left in the middle of the table, however, had already been out quite a while with the bread very dried out. Not too appetizing.

Service was prompt for a business lunch, and very friendly. The owner checked on us (Sam?) and our busboy was always making sure we were attended to with water refills and empty plate removal.

It seems the service and food can be hit and miss by the reviews, but our experience today was genuinely solid.

We're still trying new things and new places in the area! I will not rest until we try all the places! Well...

I like a good diner now and again. Sometimes they're not all they're cracked up to be though! We stopped into 7 Dwarfs for lunch one day not sure what to expect...

We ordered a bowl of Chicken Noodle soup to start. The noodles were way mushy! It was pretty salty too! 

For lunch I had the Ruben with Mashed Potatoes on the side. The ruben was ok though the bread was a little greasy. The potatoes were weird though. Very gelatinous!

The boy ordered a Patty Melt with Fries. He prefers his burgers medium rare. This thing came out well done if not more! It was way over done! 

The place is really run down and the service is pretty slow. I wouldn't recommend this place at all.

Ughh where to begin.....this place is the walmart of breakfast. Ive never had such an unpleasant dining experience.

Ive driven past here for years and always wanted to try it so today i finally did......

I should have ran after i walked in and noticed the lack of care to the interior but it was too late, i was seated rather quickly. 

I sat down and looked at the menu, placed my order and waited. While waiting i noticed the drop ceiling tiles were black with years of dust, one of the creams was opened and leaked all over the other creamers at our table. 

When our food arrived our server brought us syrup and  butter for our toast and pancakes, our toast and pancakes didnt come out, our server said they'd be brought out to us shortly. Our ham was salty and our hasbrowns were mushy ughhhh. My water that was brought to me was dirty, the rim had orange stuff on it yuuuck. After i finished eating my food i noticed a weird little black thing on my plate. I was having a hard time determining if that was char off the grill or mouse poop...when the server came and FINALLY  brought us our toast and pankcakes (by this point we pretty much finished eating) my boyfriend noticed the same black thing baked into his pancakes. ...im leaning towards the idea that that was mouse poop in our food. 

Heres the icing on the cake ... my boyfriend went to pay, he hands his credit card to the man, who i think is the owner. The owner swipes the credit card and then throws the card back at my boyfriend. I will NEVER ever set foot in here again. Terrible food, dirty, and poor service.

My parents used to go to Seven Dwarfs on dates. It hasn't changed since I was a kid and I love that about the place. The food is always great--the menu has a lot of variety and the waitstaff is excellent. It's really old school and if you've been there to eat more than once, the waitress probably knows you by your first name because most of the diners are regulars. It's nice to know that some things will never change and will always be there for you.

ATTENTION GROUPON USERS! So my girlfriend and I went to this restaurant and they are behind the times here. There is a 12.00 dollar groupon for 20.00 value. I bought this groupon since it was close to my girlfriends hospital where we were at plus I like to explore new and cool things.

There is lot of confusion between and management and groupon. Plus they don't use digital cash registers and very old school. They tried charging me the 12.00 that I already paid for and I had to explain to them that I already paid the 12.00 on Groupon. What they taught was that since my bill was 21 dollars they subtract whatever it was down to 12 dollars meaning my bill would be 9.00. But my bill would of been 1.00. The lady was Eastern European and her English was not the best so it was difficult explaining it to her. She was a VERY NICE lady though! We finally got it resolved at the end. My recommendation...if you get a groupon for this please contact the restaurant first. I don't the think the restaurant are eye to eye with groupon.

This place was not very Disney like many would think after first hearing this. There are paintings of the dwarfs and Snow White. But it's not like you are entering Walt Disney World or something.

4 stars for great service though minus the groupon situation which I don't think is their fault. The food was good. I had the fried perch and Mac and cheese with salad. It was a Friday special I think for 8.99. Very clean restaurant.

It's just a standard out of date mom and pop diner. The wow factor was not there like U Gazdy in Woodale and Toots for Train in Bartlett. But for last second good meals in the immediate area then it's a must.

This place was just weird...We came here because the Wheaton all night flea market was super packed and an hour wait just to get in. We were hungry so left to find something to eat nearby. It has a typical diner style, but the lack of people and clientele was a weird group. It felt as if we were in a deserted ghost town where everything/everyone is bleak. 

I got a soup and salad. The salad was very sad....it was pretty much all lettuce with no veggies at all! The soup was a bit too thick for me. Our server was very cold, she wasn't friendly nor mean. Not welcoming at all. Other tables got a bread basket and on the menu it said if you order soup, you should get a bread basket, but we didn't. Maybe I read it wrong though....

However, the older lady, who is the owner who checked us out was friendly to us. 

Overall, just a weird experience to say the least....

My husband and I went here with a Groupon last Saturday.  This is truly like the old fashion Greek diner.  Expect a book for a menu with so many choices, you need several few minutes to get through it all.

One item that I thought which I did not care for was the different service between the waitresses.  Ours an older lady was ok, but the younger two, oh this is going to sound petty.  Both of us order a dinner, which came with the soup.  Awesome!  She said it was a cup, but when we got it, it was a bowl.  Now the other two waitresses I noticed were giving their clients a bread bowl, for breakfast food, sandwich, basically anything.  We did not get that.  When asked she never came back with one.  Granted with all of the food we truly did not need it but it would have been better with the soup then the crackers.

Anyways, the food came, and it was ok, but that is what a greek diner is.  I would rather it be ok, than taste like crap.  But then again we are not going to a five star dining experience, so when you come here, get your priorities straight don't knock the place because they did not have the latest Starbucks designer inside.  The old sign outside should give that away before you step through the doors.

My husband and I will be coming back to try breakfast next time.  It is worth it when you get good solid food.  Plus they had Free WI-Fi to keep kids happy!

We had no problem using our Groupon here!

I like this place for a hearty breakfast or an old fashioned ice cream sundae. I find it interesting that John and Jim Belushi worked at the restaurant when they were growing up in Wheaton.  Good place.

Beware!   Filthy Kitchen. I knew of someone who made a delivery there and he said the kitchen is FILTHY DIRTY!!
He suggested to NEVER EVER  eat there!  Which is a shame because I went there on occasion and the food prices are pretty reasonable.  After he told me what he saw in the kitchen so I will never go there.  Its too bad.

It wasn't so much the decor or the sign out front, it was the food and service. I ordered a pizza burger with fruit and when the food showed up it had fries. I told the waitress I ordered fruit and she says, oh right, I'll bring that right out. She comes back with fruit and tells me that the owner wants the fries back. I chuckled because I had cut the burger in half already and there was pizza sauce on some of them. She took them off the plate at my table, with my fork, gave it back and said thank you.  I'm said I wasn't going to eat them, but are you planning on giving them to someone else. No response.. anyway the burger was frozen inside, the bun was dry and the fruit was old.. Not sure why anyone would go there, but I know me and my friends will never be going back.

I am new to the neighborhood and this will become a regular place for me.  As other reviews reveal, it is a "family restaurant/diner" with a Snow White & Seven Dwarf theme.  Food was solid and wait staff was great.  Definitely kid friendly and server was very accommodating to our little ones.

Today I tried this restaurant for the 1st time. I've passed it 100 times and today we checked it out because my friend wanted to get fried chicken somewhere. 

The restaurant was ok. The median age here was at least 70. I've never seen so many old people socializing at the same time outside of a facility built for them. lol. It smelled like corduroy pants, medicare supplied oxygen tanks and polyester shirts. hahahah... the food was ok. Great service.... nada en especial. Typical diner, but I wouldn't come back unless I HAD to. I like clean and fresh places for lunch.....not feeling like I'm taking grandma to the cafeteria. Maybe I should try them out again and see if they have the same "demographics."

Darn, sad to update my review...

We ate dinner here tonight, and though the people are so, so nice, the food and facility are subpar.

Everything we ordered was underwhelming, with the exception of the pancakes. Those were cooked to perfection. But our eggs were rubbery and the sausage was inedible.
